title: How can one determine what is political and what is not? - Quora

response.answer_text: That is a VERY broad question! I suppose you would have to add some specific context to your question. Fo example, say you want to know if a newspaper article is written primarily for political purposes of the writer, funder etc or for purely informative purposes- to describe an occurrence. Then your question is specific and can be answered. To my mind the primary factor is the stated or unstated goal of the author in writing and distributing the news item. Also, is the item simply restating a record of events ‘a fire broke out in the Dorchester Hotel last night forcing 112 quests to evacuate’ or is it an effort by the author or publisher to impact the opinion, bias, feelings of the reader. ‘Supreme Courts upholds Presidents draconian and neo- fascistic Immigration Ban in a striking blow to the human and civil rights of all of us’ in a broad sense everything to do with how a group of people choose or are otherwise compelled to share an underlying set of rules of government and law IS POLITICAL.

I view politics as a discipline that deals with coercive power, along with the authority to exercise it. As such, it considers subjects like government, sovereignty, rights, freedom and slavery, manipulation, coercion, violence, warfare, aggression and defense, justice, statutes, adjudication, legislation, elections, et cetera. The most fundamental issue of politics is arguably when we are or aren’t justified in exercising coercive power over something. Political philosophy developed to provide moral guidance (like religion does) about the rightful/wrongful exercise of coercive power. Libertarianism, for example, was an attempt to derive a clear consistent political philosophy from Christian scripture, whereas alternatives like communism arrived at very opposite conclusions. Political science also developed to scientifically study political processes in an attempt to derive general laws/principles, not through morality-based reasoning like political philosophy but only through experiment-and-observation. Political science is less concerned with right-or-wrong than with cause-and-effect, and it’s helpful in comparing the relative effectiveness of political techniques.

Today's world it seems everything has a political agenda. I went to the movies to see the latest avengers and it was filled with political statements. I thought I was going to see a movie about super heros and all I saw was how we need to embrace peoples feelings and everyone is equal. I just wanted to see shit blow up. Not to mention every netflix original ever made. Cant we just watch a movie or show with an actual story and not a political statement. How about the boycott on in-n-out, because they donated to a republican cause. Really? Lets hurt a family business because they have different political beliefs. C'mon man! How about sports? I love football. I haven't watched it in 3 years because all that's important to the NFL is kneeling durring the anthem. You make millions of dollars and your complaint about inequality? Give me a break…. The list goes on…. I just don't think that all those things should have any business in politics. It ruins everything.

Let me display my tiny amount of classical learning. The ‘polis’ in ancient Greece was the city-state and its supporting lands. It was the homeland, the thing the Hellenes gave their loyalty to. And ‘politics’ is the art and craft of living together in a ‘polis’. Nowadays the equivalent word is ‘polity’ and it means all sorts of arrangements for living together, republics and monarchies, oligarchies and theocracies and what have you. Now, whenever we are not off by ourselves in the unclaimed wilderness, contemplating our navels and the infinite whichness-of-the-whatever then we are interacting with our fellow human beings and we do it in the context of the political arrangements both formal (laws and such) and informal (customs, manners and so on) that our polity runs on. Now, when I finish this answer, drain my cup of tea and head out into the sunlight I will not be indulging in politics in the more specific sense of campaigning, kvetching about the government, standing for office or anything like that. But the bus route I will travel into town on, the shops I will go to, the lack of crime and danger on the street are all the result of political activity some of it recent (the bus franchises) some of it centuries deep (the laws governing buying and selling, the police force). So almost anything you do is done in a political context. Some more so than others of course.

When I took my Poli. Sci. course 101, the professor asked us, ‘What is politics?’ All of us freshmen and women tried to come up with erudite answers, and the professor listened to them patiently. I am sure he heard it all before. Finally he said, ‘when a husband and wife argue, that’s politics; when you try to discipline and negotiate with a child, that’s politics; when you ask your boss for a raise, that’s politics…’ I am sure you get the idea.

Pretty much everything is political, especially nowadays. It’s said that there are two kinds of people in the world, politicians and producers. Producers go to work and get the job done; politicians start acting like they’re working when the boss comes around, knows how to schmooze, etc. I would say that an example of politics would be doing things to make your opponent look bad. Doing things like lying to get votes or otherwise intentionally deceiving voters is just dishonest. One whole party in our system uses logical fallacies extensively to fool voters.

EVERYTHING is political. Health of the environment you live in, the water you drink, the school you go to, the taxes you pay, the kind of cars you see most on the roads, the price you pay for housing , the air you breath, who you are allowed to love or not, where you live, and everything else is directly or indirectly determined by your city, regional, or national governments and therefore political.

Unlike hardcore science like physics, biology etc, Subjects like politics, philosophy, literature , etc have no clear boundry. Their definition varies from people to people, nation to nation, ages to ages. Politics is just too vast and vague to draw a concrete line between what is political and what is not.
Everything is political “Politics is who gets what, when, how.” Harold Lasswell

Often, something can be seen as political if it has to do with the rules, behaviors and norms or society. As political issues are those of which governmental authorities are at least under consideration for exerting influence, anything that is sufficiently talked about in those areas can be seen as political to some. As individuals can sometimes desire for their morality to be legislated, the norms that society has can also become politically charged.
It is really easy to make that determination. If it involves ANY INTERACTION WHATSOEVER between two or more human beings, it is, on some level, political.
